--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:

> 
> Now we want to evolve the structure by having part of our genome
> describe the expression of the genome into a phenotype. Ideas that 
come
> to mind are to embed our current idea of genotype into a larger 
genotype
> idea. In this super genome, a "gene" referes to what we have been
> calling a 'network.' This network evolves using the same NEAT 
we've been
> playing with. In the super NEAT genome, each network is treated in 
the
> same way as neuron is treated. Some changes in the super NEAT might
> include mutating the number of inputs and outputs a network gene 
has (
> slowly enough for the network to work with the new topology ).
> This approach doesn't seem to me to be the best way to encorage 
profound
> symetries that drasticly reduce search space, but it still might 
work,
> and be a start.
> 
> I just felt like I had to get that out there before I started 
reading
> that paper. 39 pages. Wow. These things don't read like pulp 
fiction.
> 
> chad
> 

Chad, you may be surprised to find a form of this idea has been 
tried.  See our paper, "Evolving Reusable Neural Modules":

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco04

By the way, we don't believe this is the best way to go in the long 
run, but it's definitely one that makes sense intuitively.

ken
